summary: This document is an email chain between U.S. Department of Justice officials, including an attach√© in London, discussing a news article about Prince Andrew's refusal to cooperate with the Epstein investigation. The emails express concern from the U.S. Ambassador about diplomatic strain, reference a civil lawsuit against Prince Andrew, and discuss the status of a mutual legal assistance treaty request. The attached article details U.S. authorities' frustration with Prince Andrew's lack of cooperation and the broader implications for the Epstein/Maxwell investigations.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.role: Duke of York, material witness/suspect in Epstein investigation
persons.context: Central figure in the correspondence; U.S. authorities are frustrated by his failure to cooperate with the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's network. He is the defendant in a civil sexual abuse lawsuit and is accused of 'stonewalling' information requests.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the investigation for which Prince Andrew's cooperation is sought. His death in 2019 is mentioned, as is the exploration of his financial network and abuse of young women and girls.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Mentioned as being set to go on trial for sex trafficking charges later in 2021. Her prosecution is cited as adding strain to the diplomatic situation.

persons.name: Geoffrey Berman
persons.context: Previously stated that U.S. authorities had received 'zero cooperation' from Prince Andrew regarding the Epstein investigation.

persons.name: David Boies
persons.context: Accused Prince Andrew of 'stonewalling' appeals for information after a civil lawsuit was filed. Said his client ultimately wanted 'vindication'.

persons.name: The Queen
persons.context: Mentioned in the article as the person Prince Andrew was facing after arriving at Balmoral.

connections.description: Prince Andrew is being investigated for the extent of his ties to Epstein, including visits to his properties. The civil lawsuit alleges he was 'lent out' to Andrew by Epstein.
Described as Epstein's former girlfriend. She is facing prosecution for sex trafficking charges related to his network.
David Boies is the attorney for Virginia Giuffre, who is suing Prince Andrew. Boies has publicly accused Andrew of 'stonewalling'.
Implied connection through their mutual association with Jeffrey Epstein. Maxwell's prosecution is mentioned in the same context as the strain caused by Andrew's lack of cooperation.

events.title: Epstein's Death
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died in a Manhattan prison; his death was ruled a suicide.

events.title: Prince Andrew's BBC Interview
events.description: Prince Andrew told the BBC he had not had sex with Virginia Giuffre and had no recollection of meeting her.

events.title: Berman's Statement on Zero Cooperation
events.description: Manhattan U.S. Attorney Geoffrey Berman stated U.S. authorities had received 'zero cooperation' from Prince Andrew.

events.title: MLA Treaty Request
events.description: The U.S. Department of Justice made an application under a US-UK mutual legal assistance treaty to secure cooperation from Prince Andrew.

events.title: Civil Lawsuit Filed
events.description: Virginia Giuffre filed a 15-page civil lawsuit in New York alleging Prince Andrew sexually abused her.

events.title: Upcoming Maxwell Trial
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell is set to go on trial for sex trafficking charges later in the year.

keyFacts: U.S. authorities, including the FBI and DOJ, are 'increasingly frustrated' with Prince Andrew's failure to cooperate with the Epstein investigation over three years, causing diplomatic strain between the U.S. and U.K.
A U.S. Department of Justice request for cooperation under a US-UK mutual legal assistance treaty has not been effective.
The U.S. Ambassador in London was personally concerned about a news article framing Prince Andrew's refusal to talk as 'straining relations' and sought clarification from DOJ officials.

Investigators are interested in Prince Andrew's flights to visit Epstein in various locations (Little St James, Florida, New York) to understand travel within Epstein's orbit and potential links between money transfers and the movement of young women and girls.
British authorities (UKCA) inquired whether the civil lawsuit changed Prince Andrew's status from a witness to a suspect in the criminal investigation.
